chapter.htmlHeader: What is the prognosis?
chapter.htmlStringContent:
Episodes of sciatica are usually transient, with rapid improvements in pain and disability seen within a few weeks to a few months [NICE, 2016b].

  • A review article on sciatica cites a systematic review of randomized, placebo-controlled trials of non-surgical treatments for sciatica, where about 50% of people with acute sciatica in the placebo groups improved within 10 days, which increased to about 75% after 4 weeks [Van Tulder et al, 2010].
  • In a prospective review of the clinical outcome of 183 people with recent-onset sciatica in primary care [Vroomen et al, 2002]:
    • Of the 49 people with a poor outcome after 12 weeks, 71% had undergone surgical treatment one year after initial presentation.
    • 36% of people reported major symptomatic improvement after 2 weeks, and 73% reported reasonable to major improvement after 12 weeks.
  • A US clinical guideline states that about 50% of people with sciatica pain will have resolution of symptoms within 6 weeks [University of Michigan Health System, 2010].

A poorer prognosis has been documented in [Vroomen et al, 2002] [Manek and MacGregor, 2005; Peul et al, 2008]:

  • Women — recovery is slower and the risk of an unsatisfactory outcome is greater than for men.
  • People who initially have greater functional impairment or pain.
  • People with psychosocial risk factors, such as [University of Michigan Health System, 2010; Ashworth et al, 2011; ICSI, 2012; Toward Optimized Practice, 2015]:
    • Depression, anxiety, and stress.
    • Overprotective family, lack of support, and social withdrawal.
    • Prolonged time off work, problems or dissatisfaction at work, and reported lack of support from employer or co-workers.
    • Pessimistic expectations of ability to return to work.
    • Physically demanding work, shift work, or working unsociable hours.
    • The belief that pain and activity are harmful, with catastrophizing thoughts. 
    • Inappropriate expectations of treatment.
    • Problems with claims for compensation or applications for social benefits.
  • Recurrence of symptoms is common.
    • A US prospective cohort study (n = 605) of people in primary care with and without sciatica found that 54% of people had experienced at least one recurrence of low back pain at 6 months follow up, and 47% at 2 years follow up [Mehling et al, 2012].
    • A systematic review of 39 cohort studies incorporating 13,883 patients with sciatica concluded that people with sciatica experienced a rapid reduction in pain and disability in the first 3 months after surgery, but still had mild to moderate symptoms 5 years later. Although no significant differences were found, microdiscectomy showed larger improvements compared to other surgical techniques [Machado et al, 2016].
    • The National Institute of Health and Care Excellence (NICE) states that up to one third of patients report persistent back pain of at least moderate intensity one year after an acute episode requiring care, and that episodes of back pain often recur [NICE, 2016b].
